description:
## Description: `os` provides common OS/platform independent functions for accessing command line arguments, reading/writing files, listing folders, handling processes etc. * * * ### Security advice related to TOCTOU attacks A few `os` module functions can lead to the TOCTOU vulnerability if used incorrectly. TOCTOU (Time-of-Check-to-Time-of-Use problem) can occur when a file, folder or similar is checked for certain specifications (e.g. read, write permissions) and a change is made afterwards. In the time between the initial check and the edit, an attacker can then cause damage. The following example shows an attack strategy on the left and an improved variant on the right so that TOCTOU is no longer possible. Example Hint: `os.create()` opens a file in write-only mode
Possibility for TOCTOU attack TOCTOU not possible
```v ignore if os.is_writable("file") { // time to make a quick attack // (e.g. symlink /etc/passwd to `file`) mut f := os.create('path/to/file')! // do something with file f.close() } ``` ```v ignore mut f := os.create('path/to/file') or { println("file not writable") } // file is locked // do something with file f.close() ```
Proven affected functions
The following functions should be used with care and only when used correctly. * os.is_readable() * os.is_writable() * os.is_executable() * os.is_link()

comments.text:  args_after returns all os.args, located *after* a specified `cut_word`.
 When `cut_word` is NOT found, os.args is returned unmodified.
 args_before returns all os.args, located *before* a specified `cut_word`.
 When `cut_word` is NOT found, os.args is returned unmodified.
 Windows Registry Constants
 Windows Messages
 path_separator is the platform specific separator string, used between the folders
 and filenames in a path. It is '/' on POSIX, and '\\' on Windows.
 path_delimiter is the platform specific delimiter string, used between the paths
 in environment variables like PATH. It is ':' on POSIX, and ';' on Windows.
 path_devnull is a platform-specific file path of the null device.
 It is '/dev/null' on POSIX, and r'\\.\nul' on Windows.
 this is defined in builtin_windows.c.v in builtin
 fn C.IsDebuggerPresent() bool
 debugger_present returns a bool indicating if the process is being debugged
 `getenv` returns the value of the environment variable named by the key.
 If there is not one found, it returns an empty string ''.
 `getenv_opt` returns the value of a given environment variable.
 Returns `none` if the environment variable does not exist.
 os.setenv sets the value of an environment variable with `name` to `value`.

contents.content: fn setenv(name string, value string, overwrite bool) int
contents.name: setenv

comments.text:  os.unsetenv clears an environment variable with `name`.
 See: https://linux.die.net/man/5/environ for unix platforms.
 See: https://docs.microsoft.com/bg-bg/windows/win32/api/processenv/nf-processenv-getenvironmentstrings
 os.environ returns a map of all the current environment variables
 fd_close closes the file descriptor. It returns 0 on success.
 fd_write writes the given string to the file descriptor.
 It blocks until all the data in the string is written.
 fd_slurp reads all the remaining data from the file descriptor.
 fd_read reads data from the file descriptor. It returns the read data, and how many bytes were read.

contents.content: fn fd_read(fd int, maxbytes int) (string, int)
contents.name: fd_read
C.timeval

comments.text:  fd_is_pending returns true, when there is pending data, waiting to be read from file descriptor `fd`.
 If the file descriptor is closed, or if reading from it, will block (there is no data), fd_is_pending returns false.
/ Eof error means that we reach the end of the file.
 NotExpected is a generic error that means that we receave a not expected error.

contents.name: NotExpected

comments.text:  eof returns true, when the end of file has been reached
 flush writes any buffered unwritten data left in the file stream.
 read implements the Reader interface.
 read_bytes reads bytes from the beginning of the file.
 Utility method, same as .read_bytes_at(size, 0).
 read_bytes_at reads `size` bytes at the given position in the file.
 read_bytes_into fills `buf` with bytes at the given position in the file.
 `buf` *must* have length greater than zero.
 Returns the number of read bytes, or an error.
 read_bytes_into_newline reads from the beginning of the file into the provided buffer.
 Each consecutive call on the same file continues reading where it previously ended.
 A read call is either stopped, if the buffer is full, a newline was read or EOF.
 read_from implements the RandomReader interface.
 read_into_ptr reads at most max_size bytes from the file and writes it into ptr.
 Returns the amount of bytes read or an error.
 read_raw reads and returns a single instance of type `T`
 read_raw_at reads and returns a single instance of type `T` starting at file byte offset `pos`
 read_struct reads a single struct of type `T`

children.content: fn (mut f File) read_struct[T](mut t T) !
children.name: read_struct

comments.text:  read_struct_at reads a single struct of type `T` at position specified in file

children.content: fn (mut f File) read_struct_at[T](mut t T, pos u64) !
children.name: read_struct_at

comments.text:  reopen allows a `File` to be reused. It is mostly useful for reopening standard input and output.

children.content: fn (mut f File) reopen(path string, mode string) !
children.name: reopen

comments.text:  seek moves the file cursor (if any) associated with a file
 to a new location, offset `pos` bytes from the origin. The origin
 is dependent on the `mode` and can be:
   .start   -> the origin is the start of the file
   .current -> the current position/cursor in the file
   .end     -> the end of the file
 If the file is not seek-able, or an error occurs, the error will
 be returned to the caller.
 A successful call to the fseek() function clears the end-of-file
 indicator for the file.

children.content: fn (mut f File) seek(pos i64, mode SeekMode) !
children.name: seek

comments.text:  tell will return the current offset of the file cursor measured from
 the start of the file, in bytes. It is complementary to seek, i.e.
 you can use the return value as the `pos` parameter to .seek( pos, .start ),
 so that your next read will happen from the same place.
 write implements the Writer interface.
 It returns how many bytes were actually written.
 write_full_buffer writes a whole buffer of data to the file, starting from the
 address in `buffer`, no matter how many tries/partial writes it would take.

children.content: fn (mut f File) write_full_buffer(buffer voidptr, buffer_len usize) !
children.name: write_full_buffer

comments.text:  write_ptr writes `size` bytes to the file, starting from the address in `data`.
 Note: write_ptr is unsafe and should be used carefully, since if you pass invalid
 pointers to it, it will cause your programs to segfault.

children.content: fn (mut f File) write_ptr(data voidptr, size int) int
children.name: write_ptr

comments.text:  write_ptr_at writes `size` bytes to the file, starting from the address in `data`,
 at byte offset `pos`, counting from the start of the file (pos 0).
 Note: write_ptr_at is unsafe and should be used carefully, since if you pass invalid
 pointers to it, it will cause your programs to segfault.

children.content: fn (mut f File) write_ptr_at(data voidptr, size int, pos u64) int
children.name: write_ptr_at

comments.text:  TODO `write_raw[_at]` implementations are copy-pasted from `write_struct[_at]`
 write_raw writes a single instance of type `T`
 write_raw_at writes a single instance of type `T` starting at file byte offset `pos`

children.content: fn (mut f File) write_raw_at[T](t &T, pos u64) !
children.name: write_raw_at

comments.text:  write_string writes the string `s` into the file
 It returns how many bytes were actually written.
 write_struct writes a single struct of type `T`
 write_struct_at writes a single struct of type `T` at position specified in file

children.content: fn (mut f File) write_struct_at[T](t &T, pos u64) !
children.name: write_struct_at

comments.text:  write_to implements the RandomWriter interface.
 It returns how many bytes were actually written.
 It resets the seek position to the end of the file.

children.content: fn (mut f File) write_to(pos u64, buf []u8) !int
children.name: write_to

comments.text:  writeln writes the string `s` into the file, and appends a \n character.
 It returns how many bytes were written, including the \n character.

contents.content:
struct File {
mut:
	cfile voidptr // Using void* instead of FILE*
pub:
	fd int
pub mut:
	is_opened bool
}
contents.name: File

comments.text:  open_file tries to open or create a file with custom flags and permissions.

contents.content: fn open_file(path string, mode string, options ...int) !File
contents.name: open_file

comments.text:  open tries to open a file from a given path for reading.
 create creates or opens a file at a specified location and returns a write-only `File` object.
 stdin - return an os.File for stdin
 stdout - return an os.File for stdout
 stderr - return an os.File for stderr
 is_abs_path returns `true` if the given `path` is absolute.
 abs_path joins the current working directory
 with the given `path` (if the `path` is relative)
 and returns the absolute path representation.
 norm_path returns the normalized version of the given `path`
 by resolving backlinks (..), turning forward slashes into
 back slashes on a Windows system and eliminating:
 - references to current directories (.)
 - redundant path separators
 - the last path separator
 existing_path returns the existing part of the given `path`.
 An error is returned if there is no existing part of the given `path`.
 to_slash returns the result of replacing each separator character
 in path with a slash (`/`).
 from_slash returns the result of replacing each slash (`/`) character
 is path with a separator character.
 windows_volume returns the volume name from the given `path` on a Windows system.
 An empty string is returned if no Windows volume is present.
 Examples (on a Windows system):
 assert os.windows_volume(r'C:\path\to\file.v') == 'C:'
 assert os.windows_volume('D:') == 'D:'
 assert os.windows_volume(r'\\Host\share\files\file.v') == r'\\Host\share'
 bitmask returns a 9 bit sequence in the order owner + group + others.
 This is a valid bitmask to use with `os.chmod`.

contents.content:
struct FileMode {
pub:
	typ    FileType
	owner  FilePermission
	group  FilePermission
	others FilePermission
}
contents.name: FileMode
FileInfo

contents.content:
enum FileType {
	unknown
	regular
	directory
	character_device
	block_device
	fifo
	symbolic_link
	socket
}
contents.name: FileType

comments.text:  bitmask returns a 3 bit sequence in the order RWE where
 the bit is set to 1 if the value is true or 0 otherwise.

contents.name: FilePermission

comments.text:  inode returns the metadata of the file/inode, containing inode type, permission information, size and modification time.
 it supports windows for regular files, but it doesn't matter if you use owner, group or others when checking permissions on windows.
 open_uri opens a given uri.
 read_bytes returns all bytes read from file in `path`.
 read_file reads the file in `path` and returns the contents.
 truncate changes the size of the file located in `path` to `len`.
 Note that changing symbolic links on Windows only works as admin.
 file_size returns the size of the file located in `path`.
 If an error occurs it returns 0.
 Note that use of this on symbolic links on Windows returns always 0.
 rename_dir renames the folder from `src` to `dst`.
 Use mv to move or rename a file in a platform independent manner.
 rename renames the file or folder from `src` to `dst`.
 Use mv to move or rename a file in a platform independent manner.
 cp copies files or folders from `src` to `dst`.
 vfopen returns an opened C file, given its path and open mode.
 Note: os.vfopen is useful for compatibility with C libraries, that expect `FILE *`.
 If you write pure V code, os.create or os.open are more convenient.
 fileno returns the file descriptor of an opened C file.
 posix_get_error_msg return error code representation in string.
 system works like `exec`, but only returns a return code.
 exists returns true if `path` (file or directory) exists.
 is_executable returns `true` if `path` is executable.
 Warning: `is_executable()` is known to cause a TOCTOU vulnerability when used incorrectly
 (for more information: https://github.com/vlang/v/blob/master/vlib/os/README.md)
 is_writable returns `true` if `path` is writable.
 Warning: `is_writable()` is known to cause a TOCTOU vulnerability when used incorrectly
 (for more information: https://github.com/vlang/v/blob/master/vlib/os/README.md)
 is_readable returns `true` if `path` is readable.
 Warning: `is_readable()` is known to cause a TOCTOU vulnerability when used incorrectly
 (for more information: https://github.com/vlang/v/blob/master/vlib/os/README.md)
 rm removes file in `path`.
 rmdir removes a specified directory.
 get_raw_line returns a one-line string from stdin along with '\n' if there is any.
 get_raw_stdin will get the raw input from stdin.
 read_file_array reads an array of `T` values from file `path`.
 executable returns the path name of the executable that started the current
 process.
 is_dir returns a `bool` indicating whether the given `path` is a directory.
 is_link returns a boolean indicating whether `path` is a link.
 Warning: `is_link()` is known to cause a TOCTOU vulnerability when used incorrectly
 (for more information: https://github.com/vlang/v/blob/master/vlib/os/README.md)
 chdir changes the current working directory to the new directory in `path`.
 getwd returns the absolute path of the current directory.
 real_path returns the full absolute path for fpath, with all relative ../../, symlinks and so on resolved.
 See http://pubs.opengroup.org/onlinepubs/9699919799/functions/realpath.html
 Also https://insanecoding.blogspot.com/2007/11/pathmax-simply-isnt.html
 and https://insanecoding.blogspot.com/2007/11/implementing-realpath-in-c.html
 Note: this particular rabbit hole is *deep* ...
 fork will fork the current system process and return the pid of the fork.
 wait blocks the calling process until one of its child processes exits or a signal is received.
 After child process terminates, parent continues its execution after wait system call instruction.
 file_last_mod_unix returns the "last modified" time stamp of file in `path`.
 flush will flush the stdout buffer.
 chmod change file access attributes of `path` to `mode`.
 Octals like `0o600` can be used.
 chown changes the owner and group attributes of `path` to `owner` and `group`.

contents.content: fn chown(path string, owner int, group int) !
contents.name: chown

comments.text:  open_append tries to open a file from a given path.
 If successful, it and returns a `File` for appending.
 execvp - loads and executes a new child process, *in place* of the current process.
 The child process executable is located in `cmdpath`.
 The arguments, that will be passed to it are in `args`.
 Note: this function will NOT return when successful, since
 the child process will take control over execution.
 execve - loads and executes a new child process, *in place* of the current process.
 The child process executable is located in `cmdpath`.
 The arguments, that will be passed to it are in `args`.
 You can pass environment variables to through `envs`.
 Note: this function will NOT return when successful, since
 the child process will take control over execution.
 is_atty returns 1 if the `fd` file descriptor is open and refers to a terminal
 write_file_array writes the data in `buffer` to a file in `path`.

contents.name: Result

contents.content:
struct Command {
mut:
	f voidptr
pub mut:
	eof       bool
	exit_code int
pub:
	path            string
	redirect_stdout bool
}
contents.name: Command

comments.text:  cp_all will recursively copy `src` to `dst`,
 optionally overwriting files or dirs in `dst`.

contents.content: fn cp_all(src string, dst string, overwrite bool) !
contents.name: cp_all

comments.text:  mv_by_cp copies files or folders from `source` to `target`.
 If copying is successful, `source` is deleted.
 It may be used when the paths are not on the same mount/partition.

contents.content: fn mv_by_cp(source string, target string, opts MvParams) !
contents.name: mv_by_cp

comments.text:  mv moves files or folders from `src` to `dst`.

contents.content: fn mv(source string, target string, opts MvParams) !
contents.name: mv

comments.text:  read_lines reads the file in `path` into an array of lines.
 sigint_to_signal_name will translate `si` signal integer code to it's string code representation.
 rmdir_all recursively removes the specified directory.
 is_dir_empty will return a `bool` whether or not `path` is empty.
 Note that it will return `true` if `path` does not exist.
 file_ext will return the part after the last occurrence of `.` in `path`.
 The `.` is included.
 Examples:
 assert os.file_ext('file.v') == '.v'
 assert os.file_ext('.ignore_me') == ''
 assert os.file_ext('.') == ''
 dir returns all but the last element of path, typically the path's directory.
 After dropping the final element, trailing slashes are removed.
 If the path is empty, dir returns ".". If the path consists entirely of separators,
 dir returns a single separator.
 The returned path does not end in a separator unless it is the root directory.
 base returns the last element of path.
 Trailing path separators are removed before extracting the last element.
 If the path is empty, base returns ".". If the path consists entirely of separators, base returns a
 single separator.
 file_name will return all characters found after the last occurrence of `path_separator`.
 file extension is included.
 input_opt returns a one-line string from stdin, after printing a prompt.
 Returns `none` in case of an error (end of input).
 input returns a one-line string from stdin, after printing a prompt.
 Returns '<EOF>' in case of an error (end of input).
 get_line returns a one-line string from stdin
 get_lines returns an array of strings read from from stdin.
 reading is stopped when an empty line is read.
 get_lines_joined returns a string of the values read from from stdin.
 reading is stopped when an empty line is read.
 get_raw_lines_joined reads *all* input lines from stdin.
 It returns them as one large string. Note: unlike os.get_lines_joined,
 empty lines (that contain only `\r\n` or `\n`), will be present in
 the output.
 Reading is stopped, only on EOF of stdin.
 user_os returns current user operating system name.
 user_names returns an array of the name of every user on the system.
 home_dir returns path to the user's home directory.
 expand_tilde_to_home expands the character `~` in `path` to the user's home directory.
 See also `home_dir()`.
 write_file writes `text` data to the file in `path`.
 If `path` exists, the contents of `path` will be overwritten with the contents of `text`.
 find_abs_path_of_executable walks the environment PATH, just like most shell do, it returns
 the absolute path of the executable if found
 exists_in_system_path returns `true` if `prog` exists in the system's PATH
 is_file returns a `bool` indicating whether the given `path` is a file.
 join_path joins any number of path elements into a single path, separating
 them with a platform-specific path_separator. Empty elements are ignored.
 join_path_single appends the `elem` after `base`, separated with a
 platform-specific path_separator. Empty elements are ignored.

contents.content: fn join_path_single(base string, elem string) string
contents.name: join_path_single

comments.text:  walk_ext returns a recursive list of all files in `path` ending with `ext`.
 walk traverses the given directory `path`.
 When a file is encountered, it will call the callback `f` with current file as argument.
 Note: walk can be called even for deeply nested folders,
 since it does not recurse, but processes them iteratively.
 FnWalkContextCB is used to define the callback functions, passed to os.walk_context
 walk_with_context traverses the given directory `path`.
 For each encountered file *and* directory, it will call your `fcb` callback,
 passing it the arbitrary `context` in its first parameter,
 and the path to the file in its second parameter.
 Note: walk_with_context can be called even for deeply nested folders,
 since it does not recurse, but processes them iteratively.

contents.content: fn walk_with_context(path string, context voidptr, fcb FnWalkContextCB)
contents.name: walk_with_context

comments.text:  log will print "os.log: "+`s` ...

contents.name: MkdirParams

comments.text:  mkdir_all will create a valid full path of all directories given in `path`.
 cache_dir returns the path to a *writable* user specific folder, suitable for writing non-essential data.
 temp_dir returns the path to a folder, that is suitable for storing temporary files.
 vtmp_dir returns the path to a folder, that is writable to V programs, *and* specific
 to the OS user. It can be overridden by setting the env variable `VTMP`.
 vmodules_dir returns the path to a folder, where v stores its global modules.
 vmodules_paths returns a list of paths, where v looks up for modules.
 You can customize it through setting the environment variable VMODULES
 [manualfree]
 resource_abs_path returns an absolute path, for the given `path`.
 (the path is expected to be relative to the executable program)
 It gives a convenient way to access program resources like images, fonts, sounds and so on,
 *no matter* how the program was started, and what is the current working directory.

contents.content:
struct Uname {
pub mut:
	sysname  string
	nodename string
	release  string
	version  string
	machine  string
}
contents.name: Uname

comments.text:  execute_opt returns the os.Result of executing `cmd`, or an error with its output on failure.
 quoted path - return a quoted version of the path, depending on the platform.
 config_dir returns the path to the user configuration directory (depending on the platform).
 On windows, that is `%AppData%`.
 On macos, that is `~/Library/Application Support`.
 On the rest, that is `$XDG_CONFIG_HOME`, or if that is not available, `~/.config`.
 If the path cannot be determined, it returns an error.
 (for example, when $HOME on linux, or %AppData% on windows is not defined)
 Ref - https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/desktop/winprog/windows-data-types
 A handle to an object.

contents.name: C._utimbuf

contents.content: fn utime(path string, actime int, modtime int) !
contents.name: utime

comments.text:  mkdir creates a new directory with the specified path.
 Ref - https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/cpp/c-runtime-library/reference/get-osfhandle?view=vs-2019
 get_file_handle retrieves the operating-system file handle that is associated with the specified file descriptor.
 Ref - https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/win32/api/libloaderapi/nf-libloaderapi-getmodulefilenamea
 get_module_filename retrieves the fully qualified path for the file that contains the specified module.
 The module must have been loaded by the current process.
 get_error_msg return error code representation in string.
 execute starts the specified command, waits for it to complete, and returns its output.
 In opposition to `raw_execute` this function will safeguard against content that is known to cause
 a lot of problems when executing shell commands on Windows.
 raw_execute starts the specified command, waits for it to complete, and returns its output.
 It's marked as `unsafe` to help emphasize the problems that may arise by allowing, for example,
 user provided escape sequences.

contents.name: ExceptionRecord
ExceptionPointers

comments.text:  This is defined in builtin because we use vectored exception handling
 for our unhandled exception handler on windows
 As a result this definition is commented out to prevent
 duplicate definitions from displeasing the compiler
 fn C.AddVectoredExceptionHandler(u32, VectoredExceptionHandler)
 uname returns information about the platform on which the program is running.
 Currently `uname` on windows is not standardized, so it just mimics current practices from other popular software/language implementations:
   busybox-v1.35.0 * `busybox uname -a` => "Windows_NT HOSTNAME 10.0 19044 x86_64 MS/Windows"
   rust/coreutils-v0.0.17 * `coreutils uname -a` => `Windows_NT HOSTNAME 10.0 19044 x86_64 MS/Windows (Windows 10)`
   Python3 => `uname_result(system='Windows', node='HOSTNAME', release='10', version='10.0.19044', machine='AMD64')`
 See: [NT Version Info](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Windows_NT) @@ <https://archive.is/GnnvF>
 and: [NT Version Info (detailed)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_Microsoft_Windows_versions#NT_Kernel-based_2)
 ensure_folder_is_writable checks that `folder` exists, and is writable to the process
 by creating an empty file in it, then deleting it.

contents.content: fn posix_set_permission_bit(path_s string, mode u32, enable bool)
contents.name: posix_set_permission_bit

comments.text:  C.SYSTEM_INFO contains information about the current computer system. This includes the architecture and type of the processor, the number of processors in the system, the page size, and other such information.

contents.name: C.SYSTEM_INFO

comments.text:  page_size returns the page size in bytes.
 input_password prompts the user for a password-like secret. It disables
 the terminal echo during user input and resets it back to normal when done.
 The kind of the pipe file descriptor, that is used for communicating with the child process
 close - free the OS resources associated with the process.
 Can be called multiple times, but will free the resources just once.
 This sets the process state to .closed, which is final.
 is_alive - query whether the process p.pid is still alive
 is_pending returns whether there is data to be read from child process's pipe corresponding to `pkind`.
 For example `if p.is_pending(.stdout) { dump( p.stdout_read() ) }` will not block indefinitely.

children.content: fn (mut p Process) is_pending(pkind ChildProcessPipeKind) bool
children.name: is_pending

comments.text:  pipe_read reads a block of data, from the given pipe of the child process.
 It will return `none`, if there is no data to be read, *without blocking*.
 run - starts the new process
 set_args - set the arguments for the new process
 set_environment - set a custom environment variable mapping for the new process
 set_work_folder - set the initial working folder for the new process
 If you do not set it, it will reuse the current working folder of the parent process.
 signal_continue - tell a stopped process to continue/resume its work
 signal_kill - kills the process, after that it is no longer running
 signal_pgkill - kills the whole process group
 signal_stop - stops the process, you can resume it with p.signal_continue()
 stderr_read reads a block of data, from the stderr pipe of the child process. It will block, if there is no data to be read.
 Call .is_pending() to check if there is data to be read, if you do not want to block.
 stderr_slurp will read from the stderr pipe, and will block until it either reads all the data, or until the pipe is closed (end of file).
 stdin_write will write the string `s`, to the stdin pipe of the child process.
 stdout_read reads a block of data, from the stdout pipe of the child process. It will block, if there is no data to be read.
 Call .is_pending() to check if there is data to be read, if you do not want to block.
 stdout_slurp will read from the stdout pipe, and will block until it either reads all the data, or until the pipe is closed (end of file).
 wait - wait for a process to finish.
 Note: You have to call p.wait(), otherwise a finished process
 would get to a zombie state, and its resources will not get
 released fully, until its parent process exits.
 Note: This call will block the calling process until the child
 process is finished.

contents.content:
struct Process {
pub mut:
	filename string // the process's command file path
	pid      int    // the PID of the process
	code     int = -1
	// the exit code of the process, != -1 *only* when status is .exited *and* the process was not aborted
	status ProcessState = .not_started
	// the current status of the process
	err              string   // if the process fails, contains the reason why
	args             []string // the arguments that the command takes
	work_folder      string   // the initial working folder of the process. When '', reuse the same folder as the parent process.
	env_is_custom    bool     // true, when the environment was customized with .set_environment
	env              []string // the environment with which the process was started  (list of 'var=val')
	use_stdio_ctl    bool     // when true, then you can use p.stdin_write(), p.stdout_slurp() and p.stderr_slurp()
	use_pgroup       bool     // when true, the process will create a new process group, enabling .signal_pgkill()
	stdio_fd         [3]int   // the stdio file descriptors for the child process, used only by the nix implementation
	wdata            voidptr  // the WProcess; used only by the windows implementation
	create_no_window bool     // sets a value indicating whether to start the process in a new window, The default is false; used only by the windows implementation
}
contents.name: Process

comments.text:  - ProcessState.not_started - the process has not yet started
 - ProcessState.running - the process is currently running
 - ProcessState.stopped - the process was running, but was stopped temporarily
 - ProcessState.exited - the process has finished/exited
 - ProcessState.aborted - the process was terminated by a signal
 - ProcessState.closed - the process resources like opened file descriptors were freed/discarded, final state.

contents.content:
enum ProcessState {
	not_started
	running
	stopped
	exited
	aborted
	closed
}
contents.name: ProcessState

comments.text:  new_process - create a new process descriptor
 Note: new does NOT start the new process.
 That is done because you may want to customize it first,
 by calling different set_ methods on it.
 In order to start it, call p.run() or p.wait()

contents.name: WProcess

comments.text:  signal will assign `handler` callback to be called when `signum` signal is received.
 signal_ignore to mask system signals, e.g.: signal_ignore(.pipe, .urg, ...)
 os.Signal - enumerate possible POSIX signals and
 their integer codes.
 Note: the integer codes are given here explicitly,
 to make it easier to lookup, without needing to
 consult man pages / signal.h .

contents.content:
enum Signal {
	hup    = 1
	int    = 2
	quit   = 3
	ill    = 4
	trap   = 5
	abrt   = 6
	bus    = 7
	fpe    = 8
	kill   = 9
	usr1   = 10
	segv   = 11
	usr2   = 12
	pipe   = 13
	alrm   = 14
	term   = 15
	stkflt = 16
	chld   = 17
	cont   = 18
	stop   = 19
	tstp   = 20
	ttin   = 21
	ttou   = 22
	urg    = 23
	xcpu   = 24
	xfsz   = 25
	vtalrm = 26
	prof   = 27
	winch  = 28
	poll   = 29
	pwr    = 30
	sys    = 31
}
contents.name: Signal

comments.text:  is_main_thread returns whether the current thread is the main thread.

contents.content:
struct C.sigaction {
mut:
	sa_mask      int
	sa_sigaction int
	sa_flags     int
	sa_handler   FN_SA_Handler
}
contents.name: C.sigaction
C.stat
C.__stat64

contents.content:
struct C.utsname {
mut:
	sysname  &char
	nodename &char
	release  &char
	version  &char
	machine  &char
}
contents.name: C.utsname
C.utimbuf
